Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Wai Keung Chu of the University of California at San Diego to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at Tsinghua University in Beijing. The project title is "Analyzing Single Cells from Unculturable Samples." The host scientist is Professor Peng Liu.

Relatively few unculturable species of bacteria have been discovered and sequenced due to conventional approaches that require many cells from "clonal" cultures. A Lab-on-a-Chip device has proven the concept to identify some known species of bacteria from a mixed population of uncultured bacteria by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and flow cytometry integration (FlowFISH). This project integrates on-chip cell sorting to FlowFISH that attempts to isolate a targeted uncultured single cell for polymeric chain reaction (PCR) characterization. This project will allow quick and direct detection of bacteria that appear in uncultured samples, such as water, soil, or different clinical samples from the human body. The benefits to society may include quicker response to bacterial contamination in the environment and elucidation of the relationship between disease and human microbiome.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the resulting publications of this technology will be shared in the public domain, and among the scientific communities which attempt to detect uncultured samples, such as water, soil, or different clinical samples from the human body.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAPSI fellowship allows me to study a new method to separate rare cells from an unculturable sample efficiently without damaging any cells. The result may be universially beneficial to forensic, environmental and clinical sciences. My host Professor Peng Liu at Tsinghua University focuses on micron-sized fluidic device (also called lab-on-a-chip) for DNA technology. I have incorporated the platform of microfluidic device, which enables the manipulation of small sample size and the down-stream on-chip processing of the cellular contents. The advantages include minimal volumes and reducing sample loss. By using these advantages, I can separate rare cells from a mixed population of cells. My focus to address this scientific difficulty is on this project to separate sperm cells from rape evidence.

A surface standing acoustic wave (SSAW) cell sorting method was developed for my time at Tsinghua University. Larger objects moved toward a standing pressure node faster than the smaller objects in the microfluidic channel; cells are sorted by their effective size or volume. In the future, SSAW cell sorting method may directly feed the sorted cells into the microdevice that performs fluorescence in situ hybridization – flow cytometry (μFlowFISH), as developed by Professor Peng Liu at Tsinghua University.

This project is ongoing as mixed cells will be used for further adaptation to this technology.

During my time in Beijing, I have visited many universities, landmarks and museums in this capital city. This metropolitan area provides great traditional Chinese history and culture, while showcasing the modern and active side like any other metros in the world. A few times I tried to sit in some lectures, I was surprised to find that students were waiting to enter and the late comers would not be able to sit, or even enter the halls. The differences between China and the US were eye-opening and highly respected. An on-going collaboration with this research team in China will be continued.
